title: How to Set-up a Chain Link Fence Yourself

steps.title: Obtain any necessary permits.
steps.content: Obtain any necessary permits. Your local government may have building and zoning regulations that regulate fence setbacks, type, and height. If you install a fence without a permit, they may tear down the structure.

steps.title: Establish where your property lines are located.
steps.content: Establish where your property lines are located. This information can be obtained from city records, a realtor's line plot map, or by hiring a surveyor. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Find out where your utility lines are.
steps.content: Find out where your utility lines are. Have your utility companies mark the location of your utility lines. You don't want to accidentally hit them while digging post holes. [2] X Research source You can call 811 from anywhere in the US. Your local utility companies will then send an employee to mark your utility lines for free.

steps.title: Review any neighborhood covenants for regulations on fencing.
steps.content: Review any neighborhood covenants for regulations on fencing. Some neighborhood associations have their own rules regarding height and style, additional to the rules enforced by your town.

steps.title: Locate the property lines that border your neighbor's.
steps.content: Locate the property lines that border your neighbor's. For your post holes, measure approximately 4 inches (10.2 cm) inside those lines. This prevents the concrete footings from encroaching onto your neighbor's property. Clear the working space along the entire length of the property line to make it easier to move a wheelbarrow, as well as for rolling out the fence for installation. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Measure the total length of your planned fence.
steps.content: Measure the total length of your planned fence. This determines how many feet of chain-link mesh and the amount of hardware you'll need. Consult your local retailer for post spacing guidelines to determine the number of posts you'll need. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Find each terminal post location.
steps.content: Find each terminal post location. Mark the exact spot with a stake or spray paint. A terminal post refers to any end, corner or gate posts. [5] X Research source Spray paint works best as stakes will create a possible tripping hazard and can cause injury.

steps.title: Dig all the terminal post holes first.
steps.content: Dig all the terminal post holes first. Post holes should be dug 3 times the width and one-third the length of the post, with an extra 4 inches (10.2 cm) for gravel. Slope the sides so that the hole is wider at the bottom than at the top. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Fill the post holes with 4 inches (10.2 cm) of gravel.
steps.content: Fill the post holes with 4 inches (10.2 cm) of gravel. Tamp down the gravel to provide a compact foundation for the posts and concrete. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Stand a terminal post in the center of its hole.
steps.content: Stand a terminal post in the center of its hole. Mark the side of the post at ground level using a marker or chalk. The height above the line should equal the height of the fence mesh, plus 2 inches (5.1 cm). [8] X Research source

steps.title: Plumb the post.
steps.content: Plumb the post. Plumbing a post helps keep your fence looking straight. Using a carpenter's level or plumb line to check the balance, position the post until its plumb. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Secure the post in position.
steps.content: Secure the post in position. Using clamps and pieces of 1" x 4" x 4' to 6' long lumber angled on two sides, brace the post in its plumb position by using wooden stakes driven into ground and screws. Double check all measurements, post spacing, and height one last time before securing it to the bracing material because you do not want it to be even slightly out of alignment when the concrete hardens. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Fill the hole with concrete.
steps.content: Fill the hole with concrete. Pour or shovel concrete around the post. Smooth the surface with a trowel or small piece of wood, sloping away from the post to direct water elsewhere. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat until all your terminal posts are installed.
steps.content: Repeat until all your terminal posts are installed. Allow time for the concrete to set, according to manufacturer's recommendations. Allow at least 24 hours at minimum before putting tension on posts. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Run a string line between the terminal posts.
steps.content: Run a string line between the terminal posts. The string should be taut, low to the ground, and positioned on the outside face of the terminal posts. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Mark the location of each line post.
steps.content: Mark the location of each line post. Using a post spacing chart, measure and mark the exact spot with a stake or spray paint.

steps.title: Dig the line post holes.
steps.content: Dig the line post holes. Line post holes should be 6 inches (15.2 cm) wide and 18 inches (45.7 cm) to 24 inches (61.0 cm) deep, with sloping sides. Right before installing line posts, you can run a second, very tight line from terminal posts to set the height of line posts, but always re-check all measurements before final bracing. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Fill the line post holes with 4 inches (10.2 cm) of gravel.
steps.content: Fill the line post holes with 4 inches (10.2 cm) of gravel. Pat down the gravel to provide a compact foundation for the posts and concrete. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Position a line post in the center of its hole.
steps.content: Position a line post in the center of its hole. Use a marker or chalk to mark the side of the post at ground level. The height above the line should equal the height of the fence mesh, plus 2 inches (5.1 cm). [16] X Research source

steps.title: Make sure your post is plumb.
steps.content: Make sure your post is plumb. Go around the post with your carpenter's level or plumb line, checking to see if the post is balanced. Continue moving the post until it's plumb. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Secure the post in the plumb position.
steps.content: Secure the post in the plumb position. Add clamps and long pieces of lumber that are angled on two sides to hold the post in its plumb position. Use wooden stakes in the ground as well as screws to brace the post. Before securing the post, double check that it's straight. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Pour in the concrete.
steps.content: Pour in the concrete. Smooth over the surface of the concrete with a trowel or small piece of wood. Create a slope in your concrete so that water will slide down away from your fence post. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Continue until all of your line posts are installed.
steps.content: Continue until all of your line posts are installed. Allow time for the concrete to set, according to manufacturer's recommendations. Allow at least 24 hours at minimum before putting tension on posts. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Slide tension bands onto each post.
steps.content: Slide tension bands onto each post. Tension bands secure the chain-link mesh to the posts. Use one less tension band than the height of the fence, in feet. For example, if the fence is 4-feet high, use 3 tension bands per post. For a 6-foot fence, use 5 bands, and so on. [21] X Research source The long, flat surface of the tension band should face toward the outside of the fence.

steps.title: Add the appropriate caps to posts.
steps.content: Add the appropriate caps to posts. Terminal posts get end caps. Line posts get looped caps (for the top rail.)

steps.title: Tighten all the nuts and bolts, but not too tight.
steps.content: Tighten all the nuts and bolts, but not too tight. Leave some slack for adjustments. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Feed the top rails through the loop caps.
steps.content: Feed the top rails through the loop caps. Cut off excess length with a pipe cutter or hacksaw. If the rails are too short, create longer runs by using rails with male-female coupling ends. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Insert the rail ends into the terminal rail caps.
steps.content: Insert the rail ends into the terminal rail caps. You may need to adjust the height of the rail caps to allow for the height of the chain link mesh, plus a 2 inch (5.1 cm) clearance at the bottom. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Tighten nuts and bolts.
steps.content: Tighten nuts and bolts. After checking your top rails and caps for proper fit and alignment, tighten all the hardware. [25] X Research source

steps.title: Add your dirt.
steps.content: Add your dirt. Fill the line post holes with dirt, packing the dirt firmly around the holes. [26] X Research source

steps.title: Slide a tension bar vertically through the starting end of the mesh roll.
steps.content: Slide a tension bar vertically through the starting end of the mesh roll. This will stiffen the mesh so that you can attach it to the fence posts and rails. [27] X Research source

steps.title: Bolt the tension bar to one of the terminal posts' tension bands.
steps.content: Bolt the tension bar to one of the terminal posts' tension bands. The mesh should overlap the rail by 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) and be 2 inches (5.1 cm) off the ground. [28] X Research source You'll need someone to help you stand the mesh up to the end post and a socket wrench to turn the bolt.

steps.title: Begin unrolling the mesh.
steps.content: Begin unrolling the mesh. Stand it up against the fence frame, taking out the slack as you go. [29] X Research source

steps.title: Loosely attach the mesh to the top rail.
steps.content: Loosely attach the mesh to the top rail. Use fence ties to hold it in place. Separate enough length from the roll to span the opening between the terminal posts. [30] X Research source

steps.title: Splice sections together as needed.
steps.content: Splice sections together as needed. Using a single strand of wire removed from one end of the mesh, join two sections by corkscrewing the loose strand through the end links. A second strand may have to be removed to provide the correct line-up of "diamonds." [31] X Research source

steps.title: Remove excess mesh.
steps.content: Remove excess mesh. Using pliers, untwist the top and bottom loops on one strand of wire where you want to separate the mesh. Work the freed strand out of the links until the two sections separate. [32] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the mesh taut with a fence puller.
steps.content: Pull the mesh taut with a fence puller. The stretching is necessary so the fence doesn't sag. Thread the fence puller's bar into an unattached section of mesh, a short distance from the far end post. [33] X Research source Attach the fence puller's yoke to the pull bar and connect the other end of the puller to the far end post. Stretch the mesh with the fence puller until the mesh loops move less than a quarter-inch when squeezed by hand. If the mesh gets pulled out of shape during the tightening process, pull on it to reshape it.

steps.title: Add a second tension bar.
steps.content: Add a second tension bar. Run a second tension bar through the end of the mesh near the fence puller. This will permit attaching the stretched mesh to the far end post's tension bands.Thread the fence puller's bar into an unattached section of mesh, a short distance from the far end post. [34] X Research source

steps.title: Complete your fence with a tension bar.
steps.content: Complete your fence with a tension bar. Terminate the mesh with a tension bar on the far end post's tension bands. Remove any new excess produced by stretching. [35] X Research source

steps.title: Tie the mesh to the rails with aluminum wire.
steps.content: Tie the mesh to the rails with aluminum wire. Space your ties 24 inches (61.0 cm) apart along the top rail and 12 inches (30.5 cm) apart on each line post. [36] X Research source

steps.title: Add tension wire (optional).
steps.content: Add tension wire (optional). Thread tension wire through the bottom mesh loops. Tighten the tension wire around the end posts. Draw the wire tight and wrap it around itself next to the posts. [37] X Research source Adding tension wire prevents animals from pushing in under the fence.
